[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



     The Chairman: Estimates of Expenditure of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1996 to 31st March, 1997, contained in Paper Cmd. No 4 of 1996.

    I shall take the totals for each head of expenditure in the Main and Development Estimates appearing in the last columns of the Main Estimates and Development Outlays for FY96 on pages 39 and 40 respectively of the Command Paper. Besides the "guillotine" times for heads of expenditure, which I have fixed under Standing Order 89(7)(a), I have also allotted the time for the discussion of each amendment in the Estimates. I shall announce these times as we go along whenever necessary. We have received a record number of 417 notices of amendments. Even with the extension of the sitting time by one-and-a-half hours each day, we will still be hard-pressed for time.

    The time we have available falls short of the times Members have indicated would be required for discussion of their amendments. It will therefore not be possible to allot to Members the time they have requested. To cover as much ground as we can, I intend to keep the proceedings moving at a brisk pace and exercise the "guillotine" strictly. Members could of course help the situation by keeping their speeches short and sweet.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

Column: 1056



    Head V -

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head V of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, I had on a number of occasions in the past in this House argued that the Government consider recruiting experienced executives from the private sector for the Administrative Service. I therefore welcome the recent announcement by the Public Service Division to recruit talents from the private sector for the civil service, in particular,

Column: 1057

the Administrative Service. I think this is a step in the right direction. I say this for two good reasons.

    Firstly, unlike the 60s and 70s, when the best cohort of each group of 'A' level students applied for Government scholarships, such as President's, Colombo Plan, Overseas Merit Scholarships, the 80s and 90s saw greater competition from the private sector for the top talents. Thus, banks, statutory boards and even MNCs offer scholarships to attract our best brains to join them, the result of which is that our Administrative Service in the last 10-15 years did not necessarily have all the top brains. Hence this move to open up the service to private sector executives is an attempt to try to draw them back to the premier service.

    The second reason is this. I was once an Administrative Officer and I fully understand the utmost importance of the work of Administrative Officers as they work closely with our Ministers to chart the destiny of the country and to formulate long-term policies that affect the lives of all Singaporeans. Excellent academic and work track records and sound character and integrity notwithstanding, an Administrative Officer who has had experience working in the private sector will be able to look at issues with a more balanced and broader perspective. Indeed, I see them being able to complement and to be of great assistance to some of our Ministers and Permanent Secretaries whose backgrounds are largely from the public sector.

    Sir, while the move to recruit talents from the private sector is good, we should not necessarily restrict them to young talents in their 20s and early 30s. We should cast the net wider. In particular, we should try to attract back to the service those ex-Administrative Officers who are in the late 30s and early 40s, many of whom left the service in the mid-80s, not because they were not good but because the pay of Administrative Officers were less competitive then.

    Sir, I believe some of them are doing very well outside in the private sector and

Column: 1058

may consider, if approached, joining the Administrative Service. This group of ex-Administrative Officers, with their balanced experience in the public and private sectors, could play a valuable role in helping our Ministers to shape and formulate national policies.

    Sir, I have got one more suggestion to improve the contribution of our Administrative Officers. Some of our Administrative Officers in their late 20s and some in early 30s have become Superscale officers. While I believe they are talented and good but at that young age, many still lack the experience and maturity to look at issues with sufficient depth and width. I am therefore suggesting that the Public Service Division consider planning the career of Administrative Officers in such a way that they spend a stint of 2-3 years either in a statutory board or in a Government-linked company to acquire the necessary so-called grassroots experience before they are considered for promotion to the Superscale grade. I urge the PSD to look at these suggestions in the interest of the Administrative Service and the civil service in general.

     The Chairman: Mr Leong, you may take your two subjects together.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): Sir, the Government recently announced that it is recruiting mid-career executives in their 20s and 30s to strengthen the Administrative Service. The objectives are laudable as this will encourage the flow of talents from the private sector to the public sector. In line with this new initiative of attracting more private sector talents into the civil service, I would like to make the following suggestions.

    (1) Why not extend the entry level from mid-level to top-level? Why not take people, if they are good, at the Director, Deputy Secretary or even Permanent Secretary levels?

    (2) The Government can expand the scheme to other services, such as the Engineering Service, Legal Service, Foreign Service and others. I can imagine that these other services will benefit from the inflow of private sector professionals as well.

Column: 1059



    (3) To be able to attract the good candidates, could the Government be more flexible in offering special perks and allowances so as to better attract talents and high-flyers from the private sector?

    In the past, there has been some sense of mistrust between the businessmen and the civil servants. With the regionalisation drive, the Government and the business sector must work closer together. Over time, I hope that the above measures will see more cross-flows of people between the private and business sectors. This will lead to better understanding, mutual regard and trust, thereby creating a more cohesive Government-business environment.

    Sir, I move on to my second cut on pensioners. In the Budget Statement, the Government announced several tax reliefs and rebates. However, there is no specific tax incentive given to pensioners. Pensioners have also contributed to the progress and economic growth of Singapore, but pensioners seem to be a forgotten lot. Over the years, pensioners have not received any pension adjustments except for an adjustment announced in 1994 but this adjustment only affected pensioners who retired before 1977. No adjustments were made for pensioners who retired after 1977. Meanwhile, the cost of living has increased year by year. Hence, I would like to ask whether the Government should consider adjusting the pensions. It is fair, as other Singaporeans are benefitting from the various rebates and reliefs given by the Minister for Finance year by year. Most pensioners, especially those on low pensions, do not pay tax. Hence, they miss out on the tax rebates and income tax cut.

    The Medisave Top-Up scheme that was introduced last year for senior citizens above 65 years old is not meaningful to pensioners as they are already covered by free medical benefits, and therefore have no need for more money to be put into their CPF Medisave accounts.

    In particular, I would like to point out that there are pensioners who live in private estates, usually old terraces built

Column: 1060

by cooperatives years ago. These pensioners do not enjoy S&C, rental and utility rebates given to HDB dwellers. I would like to suggest that the Government consider allocating a special fund to cater for such cases. This fund can be administered by the Citizens' Consultative Committee of each constituency. Based on certain approved criteria and on a case-by-case basis a sum that is equivalent to the total amount of S&C, rental and PUB rebates can be paid to deserving pensioners, especially those who draw low pensions and are not living in HDB flats. Since we give regular pay revisions to Ministers and civil servants and the men-in-the-street get yearly rebates and reliefs from the Finance Minister, I thought some consideration should be given to pensioners as well.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)( In Mandarin): Sir, at the moment, the Public Service Commission grants scholarships only to those 'A' level students. With more and more students going into the polytechnics and many of them have good potential, the Government should consider giving scholarships to these polytechnic graduates as well, so that we may enlarge our pool of talented scholars. Meanwhile, Overseas Merit Scholars, normally after their graduation, will be put in high positions and they enjoy better promotion prospects than other civil servants. Will that cause some kind of unhappiness among the other officers who are non-scholars? I would like to know, among civil servants who are above the grade of Superscale E, how many of them are Overseas Merit Scholars. If two applicants are engaged, one is an Overseas Merit Scholar and the other is a local scholar, what sort of promotion prospects do they have? Are they equal? Next, how many scholarships does the PSC give to existing serving officers?
12.45 pm

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, I am speaking on medical benefits for female civil servants. Sir, I feel very bai sai to speak on this issue yet once again. But I have no choice because many people feel strongly about it and therefore the matter has to be raised once again.

Column: 1061

Many MPs have also spoken on this issue on numerous times and therefore I urge the Prime Minister to rethink the Government's stand on this issue.

    The principles for advocating medical benefits for the children of female civil servants have been enumerated many times and, basically, they are based on (1) meritocracy; and (2) welfare of the family. It seems unfair to penalise a child just because it is his mother who is in the civil service and not his father. In fact, the whole family is penalised because the disposable income of the family is affected.

    In November 1993, Dr Richard Hu, when giving the rationale for not extending the benefit to women, said that, and I quote:

    `The reason for this is not the cost of extending equal benefits to women but the principle that in our Asian society, the husband is the head of the household.' On the other hand, the Prime Minister in an interview in Bern, and reported on 24th October 1994, told some Singapore journalists that whether the head of household should be the father or the mother is for the families themselves to decide. Many Singaporeans agree with the Prime Minister.

    I am bringing up this matter again because there is a famous Chinese proverb which asserts that constant grinding can turn even iron into a needle. I hope this proves to be right. I feel the Prime Minister must be prepared to change his stand on this issue for the sake of the welfare of the family and many of us look forward to the reply.

     The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, the points raised by Mr Chew Heng Ching and Mr Leong Horn Kee concerning recruitment from the private sector.

    Mr Chew wanted to extend this scheme beyond the younger officers in their 20s and early 30s to the older officers. In principle, we will bring in people, whatever their age, as long as we can fit them into the service and they can make a

Column: 1062

contribution. We think the chances are better with the younger officers because we will have more time with them for them to learn the culture and network in the civil service, and because they are not so settled in their private careers and are more likely to consider coming back into the civil service and trying it out as a career. But, in principle, we are not restricting it to young talent if we can find somebody older, as Mr Chew suggested the former Administrative Officer keen to come back, we will seriously consider the matter and look at him.

    As for Mr Chew's suggestion that Administrative Officers should spend a couple of years in a statutory board or GLC before being promoted to Superscale G, I think that is also a good idea which we are studying. It is very valuable for an Administrative Officer not only to be sitting down writing policy at the keyboard but on the front line with a line responsibility, answerable for something ongoing and operational. It can be EDB, landing a project. It can be Customs or Immigration. It can be NRO dealing with crowds. It can be HDB having to manage people's expectations, houses, and so on. Or it can be in Singapore Telecom, Singapore Technologies, Keppel, or DBS Bank. You have seen what it is like to be on the receiving end of a directive and a policy and edict, and you come back with quite a different view of the world. So it is something which we will do. I am not sure that we can do it before they get promoted to Superscale grades. That depends on the exigencies of the service. It will take us some time to do it on a big scale because the demands for Administrative Officers expand much more rapidly than our ability to increase a pool of suitable officers. But it is something which I have a personal interest in and which I have been pushing.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee's comment on entering at higher levels, I have responded to. On bringing in mid-career officers for other services, yes, we will also do this. There is no objection. In fact, we would like to do more.

    On perks and allowances to match the private sector, I am afraid we cannot

Column: 1063

agree. We will match in terms of overall attractiveness of the package, not to lead the private sector but to be comparable with the private sector so that people who join the Administrative Service or the civil service will not have to make a big sacrifice. But we cannot match the private sector and the proliferation and the ingenuity with which schemes are invented so as to have a low nominal salary but, in fact, many de facto emoluments - housing allowance, clothing allowance, vehicle allowance, entertainment allowance and travel benefits. If we make a comprehensive list, there will be no end. So we have decided that it is far better, far cleaner, far more candid and transparent to settle on a complete amount, the total amount. We pay you this as a clean wage in the Administrative Service and the whole of the civil service. You want to go on holiday, you want to entertain your friends, you want to employ a driver, you want to buy a car, that is up to you. But we have a clean wage and overall the package is as attractive. Or we will try to keep it almost as attractive.

    Mr Leong also asked about pensioners. He averred that they were a forgotten lot, especially those who live in terrace houses and private estates. I assure Mr Leong that pensioners are not a forgotten lot. They have given many years of loyal service to the Government and to Singapore. We appreciate what they have done, and we are grateful for what they have done. Those who live in private estates will not be eligible for service and conservancy rebates and the other rebates which are based on the HDB flat status. I think it cannot be helped because we are not able to design any particular scheme to cover all the people whom we want to cover. So we have got different schemes, some covering HDB dwellers, some covering elderly folks, some covering those who need medical help, Medifund, and we hope, by an overlap of a range of schemes, we will be able to be fair to everybody, not down to the last half cent but in general terms.

    For civil servants living in landed property, I think one relevant consideration is that the value of the landed

Column: 1064

property has probably appreciated considerably over the last few years. So while in cash flow terms, they may feel that it is a little bit tight from month to month, in terms of their net assets I do not think it can be said that they have done very badly, or that they have done less well than those who have been in HDB rental or 3-room flats. So I do not think we have been unjust to them.

    For civil servants whose pensions are low, below $900 a month, as you are aware, we have a Singapore Allowance which tops it up by up to $130 which we introduced some years ago and which we revised from time to time. We last revised this allowance in 1993 when we introduced the Goods and Services Tax. Inflation since 1993 has been quite low. In 1993, it was 2.3%. In 1994, it was 3.1%. In 1995, it was 1.7%. But, nevertheless, there has been some inflation. In view of the sentiments expressed by Mr Leong, the Government will review the Singapore Allowance this year to see if there is any basis for adjusting the allowance. We will announce the outcome in due course.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang asked about scholarships, whether there are scholarships for polytechnic diploma holders. The answer is yes, because diploma holders and candidates whose qualifications are equivalent to the `A' level qualifications can apply for all the undergraduate scholarships which PSC awards, including scholarships tenable overseas, overseas specialist awards, paramedical, teaching awards and also local merit awards. However, the number of applicants has not been large. An average of 50 such applications are received each year out of about 1,300 in total. The applicants have to compete against the others for the awards which, I think, is fair. It is on the basis of merit. You come in, we evaluate you against the other candidates.

    Whether promotions are faster for scholars, they are not. When you are in the civil service, we evaluate you based on your capability. If you are good, you get promoted. If you are not good, you may have a very fine qualification from a good university but it will not get you far. It will

Column: 1065

get you at the entry point and perhaps one promotion beyond that. Because at the beginning, we have to give some credence to the track record which you have shown before coming in. But once you have established your track record inside the civil service, then we have to evaluate you based on what you have demonstrated, not based on a piece of paper which you earned some long time ago. So promotions are not automatically faster for scholars.

    How many Superscale officers are scholars who are above the grade of "E"? I do not have the data but if the Member files a question, I will get them for him. I would not be surprised if a large number are, because if we have chosen our scholars well, they will be the ones who will show potential and who, when they come into the service, will be able to perform better than average. If scholars do not perform better than average, then I will be facing another set of questions in Parliament, ie, how we choose scholars and why such duds end up receiving such generous scholarships, which has not been the case.

    As for scholarships to in-service officers, yes, we also have this. We have scholarships for general management, courses in fields relevant to the work and is part of normal career development, and we sponsor officers for formal programmes at many levels because we have a comprehensive approach to staff development. When you come in, you come in with potential. But it is our job to train you, to expose you, to groom you so that you can successively hold higher and higher responsibilities. Part of this you can absorb by osmosis because you have been on the job, you have seen what is going on, so you understand and gradually mature as the years pass. But we believe that we have to go beyond that and formally invest in people and identify them and train them so that they will be ready for higher responsibilities and they will be able to take on successively heavier and more critical loads. That we do.

Column: 1066



    Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked about medical benefits for women. She said bai sai, I am not sure what that means. There is nothing to be embarrassed about. This subject has been discussed many times and I am sure it would be discussed many times again. We have explained our position. It has not changed since last we talked about it. Dr Hu made an explanation in November 1993 and following that, in December 1993, I also spoke and we had an exchange which is in the Hansard. It is not a matter of fairness or of meritocracy. We promote people on merit. We pay people according to their contribution. But medical benefits are paid to the head of the household who is, for our purposes, the husband. It is consistent with what is put down in the Women's Charter that the father has responsibility for the children. Even if they are illegitimate children, the father has responsibility. It is right that the Women's Charter is so drafted, and I do not believe Dr Soin is proposing to change that.

    It is to strengthen this family bond and to make sure that the father takes responsibility, that men take responsibility for the children they father, that we have left the civil service medical benefits as they are, linked to the men, not to the women unless a woman is widowed or divorced. The actual quantum is small. It is becoming smaller because, with the new scheme, we have moved to Medisave and outpatient treatment, Medisave is paid in, whether to the man or to the woman. In fact, if we have wanted to be entirely consistent, we should have estimated the amount of the expense for the children and made a distinction between the Medisave for the man and for the woman. We did not do that, but a small distinction remains because for outpatient treatment, the claim on reimbursement basis only applies to the father. I think we leave that.
1.00 pm

    It is a symbolic reaffirmation that this is one cornerstone of our society. If we end up like the US or UK where one-third, approaching 40% or more, of the children are born outside of wedlock, and do not live in two-parent households - never mind married parents households - then

Column: 1067

I think our society will have fallen to bits, and all the notional rights and privileges will be meaningless. So I think we leave this be. It is not the last word, I am quite sure, but we will discuss this from time to time.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, may I seek two clarifications from the Deputy Prime Minister? First, the DPM says that diploma holders are eligible to apply for scholarships. According to his answer, they will be assessed together with the 'A' level holders. So there are different criteria, I suppose. Between 'A' level results and diplomas, how does he compare them?

    The second clarification is this. The DPM says that overseas scholars will also be assessed. Is it true that overseas scholars are given a different career path compared to local graduates? Is there any stereotype? Because they will have a higher potential in their assessment and that would affect their future promotion.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: The PSC takes many factors into account in awarding scholarships. Academic results is only one of them. You may have straight 'As' but if you do not have the character and the general range of abilities and leadership potential to be a good officer, you will not get a scholarship. I do not know how exactly the PSC trades off between a polytechnic diploma grade and 'A' level grades, but grades are not the only factor taken into account.

    As for overseas officers getting promoted faster than local ones, I can assure him that there are many overseas officers who have got nowhere in the civil service, because they have not performed. We evaluate on performance. It does us no good nor is there any reason why we should want to give somebody a birth right for the rest of his career just because he has gone to a good university. We send him to a good university expecting him to be promising. Usually we are not wrong and he goes on to do well. If it turns out that we have misjudged or later on he has become disappointing, then he goes on to a different career path. It does not take us very many years to find out after he comes back.

Column: 1068



     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, with due respect to the Deputy Prime Minister, may I seek clarification on two points, please? One is on what the Prime Minister said in Bern that we leave it to the household to decide on its head. The second clarification is that I think the Women's Charter should be changed. Because if the father is not working and it is the mother who is working, then I think the mother would have to look after the welfare of the child. And if the mother is earning more, she should proportionately put in more. Furthermore, the Women's Charter does say that the husband and the wife are responsible for the welfare of the child. It does say that as one of its tenets.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: The Prime Minister has just pointed out to me that while it is up to the family to choose who is the head of the household, 99% of the families have chosen the father, which I think is an under-estimate.

    As for the Women's Charter, both have responsibilities for bringing up children. But the father has responsibility for supporting the wife and the kids and that is a legal responsibility. The mother can go to court and enforce it, even if they are not married. The father cannot go to court and insist that the mother coughs up. So there is an asymmetry. It reflects the structure of our society. The question is whether we want to change that structure, and the Government's position is no. Dr Soin has a different view. We respect that.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, one more clarification, with the indulgence of the House.

    The SCDF was established in 1982 with the primary mission to save lives and properties. The SCDF also takes charge of operating the Public Warning System, implementing the CD shelter programme and supporting emergency activities, such as water distribution, food and fuel rationing and blood collection.

    Since its inauguration, the Civil Defence Force has undergone various organisational changes. In 1989, the SCDF absorbed the Singapore Fire Service, thus taking on the additional responsibility of providing fire fighting, rescue and ambulance services, and also regulating fire safety in buildings.

    To enable the SCDF to perform these tasks effectively, SCDF built up its strength to 62,000 men, or what you call Operationally Ready Civil Defence NSmen (CD NSmen), in its establishment. These CD NSmen are deployed in 946 units island-wide based on the concept of territorial saturation with ground forces for immediate response.

    The current structure has served SCDF well over the years. For the past 14 years, since its inception, the SCDF has successfully played a leading role in responding to emergencies to save lives and properties of our people, especially in their hour of need. But like any other organisation, the SCDF has to continually review its organisation, operation methods and structure in order to maintain its effectiveness in the light of changing circumstances. Organisation objectives must be revisited and reaffirmed in order to keep the SCDF relevant. Correspondingly, the organisational structure also must be re-examined to help the Force stay agile and dynamic. It also needs to keep pace with the recent developments in management and operational doctrines to see if these can be applied to yield more effective ways of achieving the objectives.

    In the periodic review done last year, the SCDF concluded that it can operate more effectively by forming highly trained and well-equipped rapid deployment forces based in strategic locations. This has been made possible by the maturity of the

Column: 1128

SCDF, in terms of its professionalism and experience, as well as recent improvements in the educational profile of our NSmen, thereby enabling them to undertake higher levels of training in rescue techniques and equipment. A recent study of the CD organisations in developed countries, such as Sweden and Israel, has also shown that they have moved towards this direction.

    One of the changes to be carried out after this review by the SCDF is the disbandment of the CD zone units. In place of the CD zonal units will be highly trained and well-equipped rapid deployment forces that can respond swiftly to incidents and perform more effectively in emergencies.
